Puducherry: 3 | affected = [[South India]] ([[Tamil Nadu]], [[Puducherry]], [[Andhra Pradesh]]) }} The '''2015 South Indian floods''' resulted from heavy rainfall generated by the annual [[northeast monsoon]] in November–December 2015. They affected the [[Coromandel Coast]] region of the [[South India]]n states of [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]], and the union territory of [[Puducherry]], with Tamil Nadu and the city of [[Chennai]] particularly hard-hit. More than 500 people were killed{{cite news|title=347 dead in rain-related incidents since Oct 1 in TN|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/347-dead-in-rainrelated-incidents-since-oct-1-in-tn/article7969839.ece|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=10 December 2015}}{{cite news|last=Janardhanan|first=Arun|title=Now Chennai struggles to lay its dead to rest |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/now-chennai-struggles-to-lay-its-dead-to-rest/|accessdate=9 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=10 December 2015}} and over 18 [[lakh]] (1.8 million) people were displaced. With estimates of damages and losses ranging from nearly {{INRConvert|200|b|0}} to over {{INRConvert|1|t|0}}, the floods were the costliest to have occurred in 2015, and were among the costliest natural disasters of the year.{{cite news|last=Narasimhan|first=T.E.|title=Chennai floods are world's 8th most expensive natural disaster in 2015|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/chennai-floods-are-world-s-8th-most-expensive-natural-disaster-in-2015-115121100487_1.html|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=Business Standard|date=11 December 2015}} The flooding has been attributed to the [[2014-16 El Niño event]]. ==Background== ===Geographical and meteorological explanation=== From October to December each year, a very large area of south India, including Tamil Nadu, the coastal regions of Andhra Pradesh and the union territory of Puducherry, receives up to 30 percent of its annual rainfall from the [[northeast monsoon]] (or winter monsoon). The northeast monsoon is the result of the annual gradual retreat of monsoonal rains from [[northeastern India]]. Unlike during the regular monsoon, rainfall during the northeast monsoon is sporadic, but typically far exceeds the amount produced by the regular monsoon by up to 90 percent. This excessive rainfall can be exacerbated by an El Nino year, which 2015 was.{{cite news|last=Sinha; Janardhanan|first=Amitabh; Arun|title=Extra rain and poor urban planning: Why Chennai went under water|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/extra-rain-poor-urban-planning-why-chennai-went-under-water/|access-date=9 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=19 November 2015}} The coastal districts of Andhra Pradesh usually bear the brunt of heavy rains that occur during the northeast monsoon; with numerous river systems and wetlands, Puducherry and eastern Tamil Nadu are prone to flooding. The city of Chennai alone experienced five major floods between 1943 and 2005, with the 1943, 1978 and 2005 floods causing particularly severe damage.{{cite news|title=When cities went under water|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/floods-in-tamil-nadu-cities/article7965264.ece|access-date=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=10 December 2015}} In addition, unplanned and often illegal urban development has led to many wetlands and natural sinks being built over; this, along with ageing civic infrastructure and poorly designed drainage systems, has resulted in an increased frequency of severe flooding. ===The weather systems=== On 8 November 2015, during the [[2015 North Indian Ocean cyclone season|annual cyclone season]], a [[low pressure area]] consolidated into a depression and slowly intensified into a deep depression before crossing the coast of [[Tamil Nadu]] near [[Pondicherry|Puducherry]] the following day. Because of land interaction and high vertical wind shear, the system weakened into a well-marked low pressure area over north Tamil Nadu on 10 November. The system brought very heavy rainfall over the coastal and the north interior districts of Tamil Nadu. On 15 November, well-marked low pressure area moved northwards along the Tamil Nadu coast, dropping huge amounts of rainfall over coastal Tamil Nadu and [[Andhra Pradesh]] with 24‑hour totals peaking at 370 mm in [[Ponneri]]. [[Chennai International Airport]] recorded 266 mm of rainfall in 24 hours. On 28–29 November, another system developed and arrived over Tamil Nadu on 30 November, bringing additional rain and flooding. The system dropped 490 mm of rainfall at [[Tambaram]] in 24 hours starting 8:30 am on 1 December. Very heavy rains led to flooding across the entire stretch of coast from Chennai to [[Cuddalore]]. ==Floods== ===Chennai and Tamil Nadu=== [[File:Chennai Airport submerged during December 2015 Tamil Nadu flood.jpg|thumb|left|Aerial view of submerged [[Chennai International Airport|Chennai airport] [Indian Air Force]] helicopters]] Between 9–10 November 2015, Neyveli received {{convert|483|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rainfall; rains continued to lash [[Cuddalore]], [[Chidambaram]] and [[Chennai]].{{cite news|last=Lakshmi|first=K|title=Rain wreaks havoc in coastal districts|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/rain-wreaks-havoc-in-coastal-districts/article7863341.ece|accessdate=16 November 2015|work=The Hindu|date=10 November 2015}} Continuing rains led to low-lying parts of Chennai becoming inundated by 13 November, resulting in the evacuation of over 1000 people from their homes. The flooding in Chennai city was worsened by years of illegal development and inadequate levels of flood preparedness.{{cite news|title=More rain sinks Chennai; inept corporation, illegal sites exposed|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/More-rain-sinks-Chennai-inept-corporation-illegal-sites-exposed/articleshow/49796287.cms?|accessdate=17 November 2015|work=The Times of India|date=16 November 2015}} Much of the city remained flooded on 17 November, though rainfall had largely ceased.{{cite news|title=In pics: Tamil Nadu sees sunshine, but roads still waterlogged |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/in-pics-tamil-nadu-sees-sunshine-but-roads-still-waterlogged/story-16MOD3Xomim2M9mdUkJIXM.html|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=17 November 2015}} Chennai received {{convert|1049|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rainfall in November, the highest recorded since November 1918 when {{convert|1088|mm|in|abbr=on}} in of rainfall was recorded.{{cite news|title=Chennai misses new rain record by a whisker|date=1 December 2015|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/chennai-misses-new-rain-record-by-a-whisker/article7936508.ece|work=The Hindu}}{{cite news|title=Chennai receives highest rainfall in Tamil Nadu|first=S. V. Krishna|last=Chaitanya|date=13 November 2015|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151114/nation-current-affairs/article/chennai-receives-highest-rainfall-tamil-nadu|work=Deccan Chronicle}} The flooding in Chennai city was described as the [[100-year flood|worst in a century]]. The continued rains led to schools and colleges remaining closed across [[Puducherry]] and [[Chennai]], [[Kancheepuram]] and [[Tiruvallur]] districts in Tamil Nadu and fishermen were warned against sailing because of high waters and rough seas.{{cite news|title=Rain wreaks havoc in coastal districts|url=http://www.skymetweather.com/content/weather-news-and-analysis/tamil-nadu-and-chennai-weather-update/|accessdate=16 November 2015|agency=Skymet Weather|publisher=Skymet|date=16 November 2015}} [[File:2015 South Indian flood Chennai taken by Indian Air Force helicopters.jpg|right|thumb|Aerial view of flood-hit areas of Chennai]] Though rainfall from the earlier low pressure system ended on 24 November, another system developed on 29 November, bringing additional rain and the [[Indian Meteorological Department]] predicted heavy rainfall over [[Tamil Nadu]] until the end of the week.{{cite news|title=Rain threat in TN due to fresh low pressure|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/514405/rain-threat-tn-due-fresh.html|accessdate=28 November 2015|work=Deccan Herald|date=28 November 2015}}{{cite news|title=Chennai rains: IMD predicts heavy rains in TN, Puducherry for next 4 days|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/tamil-nadu-heavy-rains-lash-chennai-to-continue-for-two-more-days/article7936729.ece|accessdate=1 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=1 December 2015}} On 1 December, heavy rains led to inundation in many areas of [[Chennai]].{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Rain-batters-Chennai-parts-of-Tamil-Nadu-Normal-life-hit-flights-and-trains-delayed/articleshow/49995842.cms| title=Rain batters Chennai|date=1 December 2015|work=The Times of India}} By afternoon, power supplies were suspended to 60% of the city while several city hospitals stopped functioning. The same day, [[Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu]] [[Jayalalithaa]] announced that, because of the continued flooding and rains, half-yearly school examinations originally scheduled for 7 December would be postponed until the first week in January.{{cite news|title=Jayalalithaa announces relief measures, half-yearly examinations postponed|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/jayalalithaa-announces-relief-measures-halfyearly-examinations-postponed/article7937054.ece|access-date=1 December 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=1 December 2015}} For the first time since its founding in 1878, the major newspaper ''[[The Hindu]]'' did not publish a print edition on 2 December, as workers were unable to reach the press building.{{cite news|title=Chennai floods: The Hindu not published for first time since 1878|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-34981328|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=2 December 2015}} The [[Southern Railway (India)|Southern Railways]] cancelled major train services and [[Chennai International Airport]] was closed until 6 December.{{cite news|last=Janardhanan|first=Arun|title=Chennai drowns in deluge of water; flight services suspended|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/heavy-rains-lash-parts-of-tamil-nadu-puducherry-normal-life-hit/|accessdate=2 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=2 December 2015}} Chennai was officially declared a [[disaster area]] on the evening of 2 December.{{cite news|title=Tamil Nadu floods LIVE: Chennai officially declared disaster zone; PM Modi takes stock of situation|url=http://zeenews.india.com/live-updates/tamil-nadu-chennai-rains-live-updates-1829037|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=ZeeNews|date=2 December 2015}} At the MIOT Hospital, 14 patients died after power and oxygen supplies failed. With a letup in rainfall, floodwaters gradually began to recede in Chennai on 4 December, though 40 percent of the city's districts remained submerged and safe food and drinking water remained in short supply. Though relief efforts were well underway across most of the area by 3 December, the lack of any coordinated relief response in North Chennai forced thousands of its residents to evacuate on their own.{{cite news|last=Yamunan|first=Sruthisagar|title=Thousands of residents flee north Chennai|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/chennai-floods-latest-updates-relief-rescue-operation-underway-imd-predicts-more-rains/article7944477.ece|access-date=4 December 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=3 December 2015}} As intermittent rains returned, thousands of displaced residents from Chennai, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur districts attempted to flee the stricken region by bus or train and travel to their family homes.{{cite news|title=As sky turns menacing again, rescue efforts intensified|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/chennai-rains-as-sky-turns-menacing-again-rescue-efforts-intensified/article7949621.ece?ref=relatedNews|access-date=4 December 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=5 December 2015}} Chennai International Airport was partly reopened for cargo flights on 5 December, with passenger flights scheduled to resume from the following morning. By 6 December, rescue efforts had largely concluded and relief efforts intensified, with the Chennai Corporation beginning to disburse relief packages. Mobile, banking and power services were gradually restored; fuel and food supplies were reaching their destinations, the airport had fully reopened and rail services slowly resumed. Many city neighbourhoods, however, remained flooded with some lacking basic necessities due to the uncoordinated distribution of relief materials. With the city slowly beginning to recover, state and national health officials remained watchful against disease outbreaks, warning that conditions were right for epidemics of water-borne illnesses to occur.{{cite news|last=Kannan|first=Ramyan|title=Displaced families count their losses|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/chennai-floods-aftermath-displaced-families-count-their-losses/article7958695.ece?ref=sliderNews|access-date=8 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=8 December 2015}} Chennai Corporation officials reported at least 57,000 homes in the city had suffered structural damage, mostly those of [[working class]] pincodes. State housing boards said they would conduct safety inspections of both public and residential buildings.{{cite news|last=Lopez|first=Aloysius Xavier|title=Chennai floods: Over 50,000 houses of low income group damaged|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/over-50000-houses-of-low-income-group-damaged/article7959676.ece?ref=tpnews|access-date=8 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=8 December 2015}} After being closed for the past month, schools and colleges across the affected districts began to reopen from 14 December.{{cite news|title=As life limps back to normalcy in flood-hit Tamil Nadu, schools and colleges reopen|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/as-life-limps-back-to-normalcy-in-flood-hit-tamil-nadu-schools-and-colleges-reopen/|access-date=21 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=14 December 2015}} Relief operations were largely wound up by 19 December. South of Chennai, heavy rains and flooding persisted into the second week of December. In Kancheepuram district, Chengalpattu, Nandivaram- Guduvanchery, Perungalathur, Tambaram, Mudichur and Anakaputhur were inundated in floodwaters up to 7 meters deep by 5 December, which washed away roads and severed rail links; 98 people from the district were reported to have died.{{cite news|title=Kancheepuram limps back to normalcy|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/Kancheepuram-Limps-Back-to-Normalcy/2015/12/05/article3161077.ece|accessdate=7 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=5 December 2015}} During 4–5 December, parts of Villupuram and Tiruvarur districts received up to 10 centimeters of rain, while some towns in Cuddalore district saw up to nine centimeters. Flood alerts were broadcast to 12 villages in the neighbourhood of the Tirumurthy dam in Tirupur district on 7 December, as the dam was likely to reach capacity within two days; the residents of those villages were urged to evacuate.{{cite news|title=Water Being Released from Thirumurthy Dam, Flood Alert Sounded in 12 Villages|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Water-Being-Released-from-Thirumurthy-Dam-Flood-Alert-Sounded-in-12-Villages/2015/12/07/article3165591.ece|accessdate=7 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=5 December 2015}} Due to rainfall in Tirunelveli district, all of its dams had reached or were approaching full capacity by 7 December, forcing local authorities to discharge thousands of cusecs of water from reservoirs and causing the [[Thamirabarani River]] to reach flood stage.{{cite news|title=Tamirabharani in spate once again|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamirabharani-in-spate-once-again/article7960266.ece?ref=tpnews|accessdate=8 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=8 December 2015}} Torrential rains inundated hundreds of acres of paddy fields in Thanjavur, Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam districts, and caused residential areas to flood by 8 December. Large parts of [[Thanjavur]] city were marooned by rising waters, while several houses collapsed under the brunt of rainfall in [[Kumbakonam]] and Veppathoor.{{cite news|last=Renganathan|first=L.|title=No sign of let-up in the downpour|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/no-sign-of-letup-in-the-downpour/article7963264.ece|accessdate=9 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=9 December 2015}} After Chennai district, Cuddalore district was among those most severely affected by the flooding. Six of the district's 13 blocks suffered extensive damage during the floods in November.{{cite news|last=Prasad|first=S.|title=Normalcy returning to rain-ravaged Cuddalore district|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/normalcy-returning-to-rainravaged-cuddalore-district/article7871231.ece|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=13 November 2015}} The resumption of heavy rainfall from 1 December again inundated the Cuddalore municipality and the district, displacing tens of thousands of people.{{cite news|title=Thousands Rescued From Flood-hit Areas in Cuddalore|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Thousands-Rescued-From-Flood-hit-Areas-in-Cuddalore/2015/12/03/article3158570.ece1|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=3 December 2015}} Rains continued through 9 December.{{cite news|last=Prasad|first=S.|title=Rain unrelenting in Cuddalore|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/rain-unrelenting-in-cuddalore/article7956414.ece?ref=relatedNews|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=7 December 2015}} Despite the state government and individuals sending rescue teams and tonnes of relief materials to the district, thousands of those affected continued to lack basic supplies due to inadequate distribution efforts; this resulted in several relief lorries being stopped and looted by survivors.{{cite news|last=Yamunan|first=Sruthisagar|title=In Cuddalore, desperate crowds snatch relief materials from trucks|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/in-cuddalore-desperate-crowds-snatch-relief-material-from-trucks/article7958703.ece?ref=relatedNews|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=8 December 2015}} Large swaths of [[Cuddalore]] city and the district remained inundated as of 10 December, with thousands of residents marooned by floodwaters and over 60,000 hectares of farmland inundated; over 30,000 people had been evacuated to relief camps.{{cite news|last=Yamunan; Sivaraman|first=Sruthisagar; R.|title=Cuddalore still under water, thousands cut off|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamil-nadu-floods-cuddalore-still-under-water-thousands-cut-off/article7962573.ece?ref=relatedNews|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=10 December 2015}} The state government reported preliminary flood damages of {{INRConvert|8481|c|0}}, and requested {{INRConvert|2000|c|0}} for immediate relief efforts.{{cite web | title=Tamil Nadu government pegs flood damage at Rs 8,481 crore, CM Jayalalithaa writes to PM Modi | website=dna | date=23 November 2015 | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-tamil-nadu-government-pegs-flood-damage-at-rs-8481-crore-cm-jayalalithaa-writes-to-pm-modi-2148012 | access-date=23 November 2015}} On 5 December, a senior state revenue official said the state's official estimates of flood-related losses in November alone exceeded {{INRConvert|9800|c|0}}; he added the catastrophic flooding thus far in December could escalate total losses to well over {{INRConvert|100000|c|0}}.{{cite news|last=Kotteswaran|first=C.S.|title=Tamil Nadu: Chennai floods cause a loss of Rs 50,000-cr|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151206/nation-current-affairs/article/chennai-floods-caused-loss-50-thousand-crore|accessdate=9 December 2015|work=Deccan Chronicle|date=6 December 2015}} On 9 December, Chief Minister Jayalalithaa wrote to Prime Minister Modi, requesting him to immediately declare the "unprecedented, catastrophic and cataclysmic" flooding as a "national calamity."{{cite news|last=Janardhanan|first=Arun|title=Declare Chennai floods national calamity, Jayalalithaa urges PM Modi|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/jayalalithaa-urges-pm-modi-to-declare-chennai-floods-as-national-calamity/ |access-date=9 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=9 December 2015}} Aon Benfield, a major UK-based reinsurance broker, classified the floods as the costliest to have occurred in 2015, and the eight-costliest natural disaster of the year. On 13 December, the state government requested the central government to release a total of ₹10,250 crore (US$1.53 billion) towards relief and rehabilitation efforts, including {{INRConvert|5000|c|0}} for a housing project to accommodate 50,000 displaced people, {{INRConvert|750|c|0}} to rehouse another 50,000 people who had formerly lived in huts destroyed by the floods and {{INRConvert|4500|c|0}} to rebuild damaged roads, drains, tap water pipes and sewers in urban localities.{{cite news|title=Jayalalithaa Seeks Rs 10,250 Crore for Flood Victims |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Jayalalithaa-Seeks-Rs-10250-Crore-for-Flood-Victims/2015/12/13/article3175952.ece |access-date=20 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=13 December 2015}} On 22 December, the government further revised its estimates, requesting ₹17,431.51 crore (US$2.63 billion) in addition to the ₹8481 crore previously requested for the flood damage sustained in November, for a total of ₹25,912.51 crore (US$3.91 billion).{{cite news|title=TN Floods: CM Jaya Seeks Rs 25,912 Crore for Restoration Work |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/TN-Floods-CM-Jaya-Seeks-Rs-25912-Crore-for-Restoration-Work/2015/12/22/article3190817.ece |access-date=22 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=22 December 2015}} In January 2016, the state government issued a detailed final statement which said 421 people in Tamil Nadu had died of flood-related causes between 28 October, when the first monsoonal rains had arrived in earnest, through 31 December;Not including 49 people who had died between 1–28 October as a result of the monsoon.{{cite news|title=Northeast monsoon claimed 470 lives in Tamil Nadu: Jayalalithaa |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/national/northeast-monsoon-claimed-470-lives-in-tamil-nadu-jayalalithaa/article8064661.ece |access-date=22 January 2016|work=Business Line|date=4 January 2016}}{{cite news|last=Janardhanan|first=Arun|title=Chennai floods: Students to homemakers, citizens take lead in relief operations|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/chennai-floods-students-to-homemakers-citizens-take-lead-in-relief-ops/ |access-date=8 December 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=8 December 2015}}{{cite news|title=Rains continue in Tamil Nadu; toll climbs past 170|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/rains-continue-in-tamil-nadu-toll-climbs-past-170/article7916090.ece |access-date=26 November 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=25 November 2015}} however, relief workers alone had reported hundreds more who were missing, and various police reports had placed the death toll in the Chennai region alone at over 500 as of mid-December. Chennai-area morgues and crematoria were reported to have been "piled up" with bodies as floodwaters began receding in the second week of December, while all of the still-functioning area cemeteries had recorded over three times the usual number of burials, up from a normal 25–30 burials per week.{{cite news|title=How Many Lives Have Been Lost in Tamil Nadu Floods?|url=http://www.thequint.com/hot-wire/2015/12/12/how-many-lives-have-been-lost-in-tamil-nadu-floods|access-date=22 January 2016|publisher=The Quint|date=12 December 2015}} According to the Tamil Nadu government, 30.42 lakh (3.042 million) families had suffered total or partial damage to their dwellings. 3,82,768 lakh hectares of crops had been lost due to flooding, including over 3.47 lakh hectares of agricultural crops and 35,471 hectares of horticultural crops; roughly 98,000 livestock animals and poultry had died. ===Puducherry=== Puducherry sustained relatively minor damage in November as the depression largely remained offshore; some trees were downed and several banana and sugarcane plantations at Kuttchipalayam were severely damaged.{{cite news|title=Comparatively Mild, but Puducherry Battered |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Comparatively-Mild-but-Puducherry-Battered/2015/11/10/article3121969.ece|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=10 November 2015}} Puducherry reported receiving 55.7 mm of rainfall over the 24-hour period from 14–15 November. Water entered several houses in low-lying areas, while three houses collapsed in Uppalam. Mudaliarpet, parts of Rainbow Nagar, Muthialpet, Krishna Nagar and Lawspet Main Road were inundated, along with portions of roadways near Karuvadikkuppam and the Shivaji statue on the ECR, causing traffic problems. Several roads were badly damaged, hindering motorists, while some members of the public took the initiative to begin clearing areas of water without directions from the government. Chief Minister [[N. Rangasamy|N Rangasamy]] stated the official machinery had been readied in preparation for any flooding, while local administration officials closed all schools and colleges in Puducherry and Karaikal districts on 16 November, anticipating further rainfall.{{cite news|title=Low-lying Areas Inundated, Puducherry Wades Through|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Low-lying-Areas-Inundated-Puducherry-Wades-Through/2015/11/16/article3130502.ece|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=17 November 2015}} On 24 November, it was reported over 4800 hectares of farmland had been flooded, though it remained too early to determine the extent of crop damage.{{cite news|title=More than 4800 hectares of farm land estimated to be inundated|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/more-than-4800-hectares-of-farm-land-esimated-to-be-inundated-115112401139_1.html|accessdate=25 November 2015|work=Business Standard|date=24 November 2015}} On 26 November, the union territorial government submitted a preliminary estimate of damages to the central government, requesting it to release an initial {{INRConvert|182.45|c|0}} for relief; based on preliminary estimates, Chief Minister Rangasamy reported losses as follows: public works ({{INRConvert|120.89|c|0}}), municipal administration ({{INRConvert|48.66|c|0}}), agriculture ({{INRConvert|7.2|c|0}}), power ({{INRConvert|3.14|c|0}}), revenue ({{INRConvert|2.48|c|0}}) and animal husbandry ({{INRConvert|7.19|l|0}}).{{cite news|title=Puducherry seeks Rs 182.45 crore immediate flood relief assistance|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Puducherry-seeks-Rs-182-45-crore-immediate-flood-relief-assistance/articleshow/49938116.cms|accessdate=26 November 2015|work=The Times of India|date=26 November 2015}} On 1 December, Rangasamy requested an additional {{INRConvert|100|c|0}} for "immediate interim relief".{{cite news|title=N Rangasamy seeks interim financial assistance of Rs 100 crore from govt|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/n-rangasamy-seeks-interim-financial-assistance-of-rs-100-crore-from-govt/articleshow/49997961.cms|accessdate=1 December 2015|work=The Economic Times|date=1 December 2015}} At the start of December, Puducherry reported receiving 83.4 centimeters of rain during November alone, as opposed to a normal average of 76.7 centimeters during the entire north-east monsoonal period from October to December.{{cite news|title=Puducherry Pounded by 83.4 Centimeter Rainfall in November Alone|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Puducherry-Pounded-by-83.4-Centimeter-Rainfall-in-November-Alone/2015/12/03/article3158035.ece|accessdate=4 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=3 December 2015}} Since rain-related damage had continued even after the submission of a report on the earlier flooding in November, and also after the recent visit of a central government survey team, on 4 December the Puducherry government said it would submit a supplementary report assessing additional damages and requesting {{INRConvert|150|c|0}} for a total relief-fund requirement of {{INRConvert|333|c|0}}. From 1 December, torrential rains again inundated portions of the union territory. Puducherry recorded 22 cm of rainfall over a 24-hour period, making it the wettest December day ever. Heavy rain beginning on the evening of 4 December flooded parts of Puducherry, continuing through the following morning. According to the Regional Meteorological Centre, Chennai, Puducherry received nine centimeters of rain during this period. Puducherry District Collector D.Manikandan, said the rainfall had been "unprecedented in Puducherry, and the volume has been the highest [since] 1975." The administration said that 618 houses had been damaged thus far and over 2,000 people evacuated to safe places. On 5 December, the Karaikal region recorded 110 centimeters of rainfall since the start of the north-east monsoon.{{cite news|title=Marakkanam, Nannilam receive record rainfall|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/puducherry/marakkanam-nannilam-receive-record-rainfall/article7954946.ece|accessdate=6 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=6 December 2015}} In Karaikal, an enclave of Puducherry, nearly 50 houses were damaged due to heavy rain and flooding. On 5 December, the territorial government announced that nearly 9,000 hectares of paddy fields had been damaged by torrential rainfall, including 4,420 hectares of paddy fields in Puducherry,4,248.34 hectares in Karaikal and 287.15 hectares in Yanam. The government also reported 1,544 hectares of sugercane fields under cultivation had been damaged, along with 297.73 hectares of plantains, 231.9 hectares of tapioca and related tubers, 168.10 hectares of vegetable fields and eight hectares under betel-leaf cultivation. Proposed compensation rates would be as follows: {{INRConvert|50|k|0}}) per hectare for betel-leaf losses, {{INRConvert|35|k|0}}) per hectare for plantains, {{INRConvert|20|k|0}}) per hectare for paddy fields and {{INRConvert|15|k|0}}) per hectare for losses of vegetables, tapioca, tubers and sugercane. Compensation scales had also been set for losses of cotton, lentils and flowers.{{cite news|title=Puducherry: Over 8,900 hectare area under paddy lost in rain|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/puducherry-over-8900-hectare-area-under-paddy-lost-in-rain/article7951890.ece|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=5 December 2015}} G. Sundaramurthy, a 62-year-old man in [[Ariyankuppam]], was killed on 9 November when a mud wall collapsed, while Anandan, a 53-year-old man in Ouppalam, was subsequently reported to have died because of the rain.{{cite news|title=Anbazhagan Flays Rangasamy Over Rain Relief Failure|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Anbazhagan-Flays-Rangasamy-Over-Rain-Relief-Failure/2015/11/16/article3130196.ece|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=16 November 2015}} On 17 November, S. Chellammal, a 72-year-old woman in Karayamputhur, was killed by the collapse of a rain-weakened mud wall.{{cite news|title=Wall Collapse Kills 70-year-old Woman in Karayamputhur|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Wall-Collapse-Kills-70-year-old-Woman-in-Karayamputhur/2015/11/18/article3133565.ece|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=18 November 2015}}{{cite news|title=CM hands over Rs. 4 lakh each to kin of victims|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/puducherry/cm-hands-over-rs-4-lakh-each-to-kin-of-victims/article7974124.ece?ref=tpnews|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=12 December 2015}} ===Andhra Pradesh=== The Season began on November 9th, with a Depression hitting Tamilnadu. Rainfall begin pour in the places of Nellore and Chittor district. Tirumala getting a heavy rainfall of 309mm along with Tirupathi with 148mm in 24 hours triggered a flood situation in Chittoor District. Coastal places of Tada recorded 114mm of rainfall the same day. There were 3-4 good spells of rain between 9th and 15th. As rainfall began in [[Andhra Pradesh]] on 16 November, local authorities closed schools in [[Nellore district]]. Heavy rain of about 27 cm pounded the temple town of Tirupathi. Thousands of lakes and ponds across the district overflowed, with breaches reported in some areas. At Sri Kalahasti, a pilgrimage centre in the region, the [[Swarnamukhi]] River was reported to be rising. Three people were swept away by floodwaters in Chittoor district, and water entered some houses. Roads were damaged in many parts of [[Nellore district]], disrupting transport services. Andhra Pradesh chief minister [[Chandrababu Naidu]] held a teleconference with the [[district collector]]s of affected districts and asked disaster response personnel to be on alert. Heavy rainfall in Nellore, Chittoor and Kadapa districts flooded villages and disrupted transport networks. It was estimated by 18 November that at least 500 km of roads had been damaged by flooding, with the Chennai-Kolkata highway damaged the previous day and stranding hundreds of vehicles and motorists; officials said it would take days to restore the link. As in Tamil Nadu, the [[Southern Railway zone|Southern Railway]] diverted or cancelled numerous trains.{{cite news|title=As rains relent in Tamil Nadu, incessant downpour batters Andhra|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/as-rains-relent-in-tamil-nadu-incessant-downpour-batters-andhra/story-6lAwKUwgbaruuq8fjYin3L.html|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=18 November 2015}} Over 10,000 lorry drivers were stranded on the Tada-Kavali national highway in Nellore district; district officers established 61 relief camps in the flood-affected areas and deputed senior IAS officers to oversee the relief operations in Gudur, Naidupet and Atmakur divisions, respectively. Up to 500 tanks were breached as rivers overflowed, forcing the administration to suspend rescue operations in marooned villages, though administrators supplied 10,000 food and water packets through the rail network, which managed to operate some trains, while the APSRTC continued to run bus services to less-flooded areas such as Atmakuru, Udayagiri, Marripadu and Seetharampuram.{{cite news|title=Rain Batters Nellore, Relief Operations Hit|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/Rain-Batters-Nellore-Relief-Operations-Hit/2015/11/19/article3135851.ece|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=19 November 2015}} In Kadapa district, the rains tapered off by 18 November; preliminary estimates were that the district had sustained about {{INRConvert|29|c|0}} of agricultural losses. Horticulture farms at Pendlimerry, Chintakommadinne, Siddhavatam and Khajipet mandals were also destroyed by the rain. Other heavy agricultural losses were reported in Rayalaseema, Nellore, Prakasam, East and West Godavari districts; the chief minister asked agriculture department officials to drain fields at the earliest in order to save crops.{{cite news|title=More Rescue Teams Sent to Nellore Dist|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/More-Rescue-Teams-Sent-to-Nellore-Dist/2015/11/19/article3135865.ece|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=19 November 2015}} In a letter to Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] on 19 November, Chief Minister Naidu reported preliminary estimates of flood-related damage in Andhra Pradesh included {{INRConvert|1250|c|0}} worth of agricultural-related damages and {{INRConvert|1025|c|0}} of damage to infrastructure; he requested central authorities to release {{INRConvert|1000|c|0}} for immediate relief efforts.{{cite news|title=AP CM asks Centre to release Rs 1,000 cr for relief operations|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/ap-cm-asks-centre-to-release-rs-1-000-cr-for-relief-operations-115111901079_1.html|accessdate=20 November 2015|work=Business Standard|date=19 November 2015}} According to Naidu, Nellore district was the most seriously affected, reporting an estimated {{INRConvert|1395|c|0}} worth of losses, followed by Chittoor district, which reported losses of {{INRConvert|818|c|0}}. Kadapa district was also seriously affected, with extensive crop damage reported in East and West Godavari districts and a lesser scale of damage in Anantapur, Prakasam and Krishna districts. The [[aquaculture]] industry in Nellore district was catastrophically affected, with over 8000 hectares of fish and prawn ponds destroyed, at an estimated loss of {{INRConvert|250|c|0}}.{{cite news|last=Rajulapudi|first=Srinivas|title=Floods in Nellore may hit seafood exports this year|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Vijayawada/floods-in-nellore-may-hit-seafood-exports-this-year/article7918457.ece|accessdate=1 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=24 November 2015}} On 2 December, Thota Narasimham, an MP from the [[Telugu Desam Party]], reported in the Lok Sabha that preliminary losses in the state roughly totalled {{INRConvert|3819|c|0}}.{{cite news|last=Rishi Kumar|first=V.|title=Rains batter AP; loss put at ₹3,819 crore|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/national/rains-batter-ap-loss-put-at-3819-crore/article7941837.ece|accessdate=3 December 2015|work=Business Line|date=3 December 2015}} Heavy rains resumed on 2 December, adding to the devastation in Nellore and Chittoor districts, with more rains forecast over the ensuing days; Chittoor district received between 50–160 mm of rainfall. Chief Minister Naidu directed district officials and health, water and sanitation officers to organise water purification and set up medical relief camps.{{cite news|title=High alert in AP as Nellore, Chittoor flooded|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/High-alert-in-AP-as-Nellore-Chittoor-flooded/articleshow/50027745.cms|accessdate=4 December 2015|work=The Times of India|date=3 December 2015}} On 4 December, Andhra Pradesh Home Minister [[Nimmakayala Chinarajappa]] reported heavy infrastructural losses in Nellore and Chittoor districts, with heavy agricultural losses in Godavari district; he added that over 5,00,000 acres of standing crops had been destroyed, and that the state government had requested {{INRConvert|3750|c|0}} in immediate relief funds from the central government.{{cite news|title=81 killed in rains so far, says Home Minister|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/81-killed-in-rains-so-far-says-home-minister/article7946764.ece?ref=tpnews|accessdate=4 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=4 December 2015}} At the start of December, Chittoor district recorded 65.1 cm of rain over the monsoonal season thus far, as opposed to a normal 16.1 cm of rainfall. 2,429 hectares of crops in the district were damaged, including 1,790 hectares of paddy that had been submerged. A further 3,039 hectares of horticultural crops were also damaged. After a central government survey team completed an assessment of the flood-hit districts on 12 December, the state government submitted a final revised estimate of damages from the November and December floods; the memorandum stated that the flooding had caused {{INRConvert|4960|c|0}} worth of damages and losses.{{cite news|title=Rain loss: govt. to submit revised memo to Centre|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/rain-loss-govt-to-submit-revised-memo-to-centre/article8019711.ece?ref=tpnews|accessdate=28 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=23 December 2015}} As of 4 December 81 people were reported to have been killed by flooding in the state, while over 14,000 people had been evacuated to relief camps in Nellore and Chittoor districts.{{cite news|title=Andhra Pradesh: 4 children killed as wall collapses due to rains |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/andhra-pradesh-4-children-killed-as-wall-collapses-due-to-rains/story-VeqGq5pxYEXJeM3tCbH13M.html|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=18 November 2015}} == Consequences of flooding == Supplies of basic necessities, including milk, water and vegetables, were affected due to logistical difficulties. During the December floods in Chennai and the adjoining areas, milk packets sold for {{INRConvert|100}}, five times more than their usual cost. Water bottles and cans were sold at prices between {{INRConvert|100}} to {{INRConvert|150}}. Vegetables were sold at least {{INRConvert|10}} to {{INRConvert|20}} over and above their normal average cost at the wholesale level.{{cite news|title=Residents stock up for the rainy day|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/residents-stock-up-for-the-rainy-day/article7951811.ece?css=print|accessdate=5 December 2015|work=The Hindu|issue=5 December 2015|location=Chennai}} Apart from basic necessities, fuel supplies and travel were greatly affected, especially in Chennai.{{cite news|title=Chennai fuel crisis: Fuel supply disrupted in Tamil Nadu’s rain-hit capital|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/india-news/chennai-fuel-crisis-fuel-supply-disrupted-in-tamil-nadus-chennai-floods/174366/|accessdate=5 December 2015|work=The Financial Express|agency=Press Trust of India|date=4 December 2015}} Numerous accounts of price-gouging were reported; airfares to and from for most parts of South India peaked to almost 10 times over their normal price. A round trip fare from Mumbai or New Delhi to Bangalore, Karnataka (the nearest accessible city to Chennai, Tamilnadu) was sold by airlines like [[Jet Airways]] at rates of almost {{INRConvert|1|l}}, a trip which would have ordinarily cost between {{INRConvert|10|k}} to {{INRConvert|20|K}}.{{cite news|title=With Chennai airport shut, |accessdate=5 December 2015|work=DNA India|date=5 December 2015|location=Chennai}} Apart from airfares in South India, airfares also increased for other connections within the country, due to disruptions in rail services.{{cite news|title=Airfares up as rail disruptions push people to fly|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Airfares-up-as-rail-disruptions-push-people-to-fly/articleshow/49838831.cms|accessdate=5 December 2015|work=The Times of India|date=19 November 2015|location=Chennai}} In response, the [[Ministry of Civil Aviation (India)|Ministry of Civil Aviation]] warned companies against taking advantage of the situation to overcharge and that it would intervene if any of the passenger flight carriers did so. On its own, the civil aviation ministry also operated flights from the Rajali naval airbase in Arakonam, Chennai with a fixed price of {{INRConvert|2|k}} per passenger for travel to the northern states and {{INRConvert|1|k}} per passenger for travel to the southern states.{{cite news|author1=Mihir Mishra|title=Chennai rains: Aviation ministry warns airlines not to flood their coffers with extra money|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/transportation/airlines-/-aviation/chennai-rains-aviation-ministry-warns-airlines-not-to-flood-their-coffers-with-extra-money/articleshow/50034791.cms|accessdate=6 December 2015|date=4 December 2015|location=New Delhi}} In Chennai, over 1.5 lakh (150,000) street vendors sustained losses of over {{INRConvert|300|c|0}}.{{cite news|title=Over 1.5 lakh street vendors affected|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/over-15-lakh-street-vendors-affected/article8023454.ece|access-date=24 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=24 December 2015}} The persistent rainfall and flooding forced several major automakers in the region, including [[Ford]], [[Renault]], [[Nissan]] and [[Daimler AG]], to temporarily halt production, resulting in estimated losses of up to {{INRConvert|1000|c|0}}.{{cite news|last=Lakshmana|first=K.V.|title=Chennai rains may have sunk businesses worth thousands of crores |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/business/chennai-rains-may-have-sunk-businesses-worth-thousands-of-crores/story-dCUi5GHoQPmdddpRk2rLQM.html|accessdate=8 December 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=8 December 2015}} Industry analysts estimated total industrial losses as a result of the floods to be in the range of ₹10,000 to ₹15,000 crore (US$1.52 billion to US$2.27 billion). All of the major auto- and truck-makers in the Oragadam and Sriperumbudur manufacturing belts resumed operations by 8 December, despite ongoing damage assessments; some employees were forced to continue working from their homes.{{cite news|last=Balachandar|first=G.|title=Vehicle makers sans Ford resume production at Chennai factories|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/tamil-nadu-floods-vehicle-makers-sans-ford-resume-production-at-chennai-factories/article7958524.ece |access-date=7 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=7 December 2015}} Many major information technology companies, including [[Infosys]] and Tata Consultancy Services, closed their offices and had their employees work from their homes, or transferred operations to other locations in cities including Pune and Bengaluru.{{cite news|title=When Chennai was logged out and how|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151203/nation-current-affairs/article/when-chennai-was-logged-out-and-how|accessdate=9 December 2015|work=Deccan Chronicle|date=3 December 2015}} Prices of vegetables and fruits significantly increased, as over 50% of supplies were affected after numerous lorries were stranded.{{cite news|title=Tamil Nadu's deadly rains hit industries hard |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/514696/tamil-nadus-deadly-rains-hit.html|accessdate=1 December 2015|work=Deccan Herald|date=30 November 2015}} The Indian Oil Corporation was forced to close its large Manali refinery in Chennai because of the floods. Popular television networks, namely [[Puthiya Thalaimurai]], [[Jaya TV]] and [[Mega TV (Tamil)|Mega TV]] halted services following flood-related technical difficulties. Motorcycle producer [[Royal Enfield (India)|Royal Enfield]] shut its Chennai offices on 1 December, as well as its plants in [[Thiruvotriyur]] and [[Oragadam]], which had already lost the production of 4,000 motorcycles in November.{{cite news|author1=|title=Production at Royal Enfield’s Chennai plant hit by floods|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/production-at-royal-enfields-chennai-plant-hit-by-floods/article7945318.ece|accessdate=4 December 2015|work=[[Business Line]]|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]|date=3 December 2015}} The Chennai real estate market sustained an estimated loss of nearly {{INRConvert|30000|c}},{{cite news|title=Chennai realty market faces Rs 30,000 crore loss post floods|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-chennai-realty-market-faces-rs-30000-crore-loss-post-floods-2160122|access-date=28 December 2015|publisher=DNA|date=28 December 2015}} while over 20,000 small and medium industrial units across Tamil Nadu reported total losses of over {{INRConvert|14000|c}}.{{cite news|title=Flood-hit Industrial Belts Clamour for Aid |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/Flood-hit-Industrial-Belts-Clamour-for-Aid/2015/12/27/article3198021.ece|access-date=28 December 2015|work=The New Indian Express|date=28 December 2015}} Insurers in India estimated they would receive claims totalling over {{INRConvert|1000|c}} for losses to property, cargo and inventory, mostly from auto companies.{{cite news|author1=Shilpy Sinha|title=Chennai floods: Insurance companies likely to face claims worth Rs 1,000 crore|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/chennai-floods-insurance-companies-likely-to-face-claims-worth-rs-1000-crore/articleshow/50035351.cms|accessdate=5 December 2015|work=The Economic Times|date=4 December 2015|location=Mumbai}} During the first period of floods, claims worth about {{INRConvert|500|C}} were settled by various general insurance companies in India, largely from shopkeepers and vehicle owners. According to the [[General Insurance Corporation of India]], another large amount of claims was expected to be reported by automobile companies based in South India.{{cite web|author=Accord Fintech|title= Insurance companies likely to face claims worth Rs 1,000 crore|url=http://money.livemint.com/news/insurance/news/insurance-companies-likely-to-face-claims-worth-rs-1-000-crore--413982.aspx|publisher=LiveMint|accessdate=5 December 2015|location=Mumbai|date=4 December 2015}} The General Insurance giant of India, the [[New India Assurance]] alone received claims amounting about {{INRConvert|425|c}} from about 1,700 claims submissions till mid December.{{cite news|title=TN rains: New India Assurance pegs flood claims at Rs 500 crore|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/wealth/news/tn-rains-new-india-assurance-pegs-flood-claims-at-rs-500-crore/articleshowsp/50142526.cms|accessdate=18 December 2015|work=The Economic Times|agency=Press Trust of India|date=11 December 2015}} By late January 2016, various insurers reported they had received roughly 50,000 damage claims totalling {{INRConvert|4800|c}}.{{cite news|title=Chennai floods: Insurance cos get Rs 4,800 cr claims|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/chennai-floods-insurance-cos-get-rs-4800-cr-claims/|accessdate=22 January 2016|work=The Indian Express|date=23 January 2016}} Several Indian IT giants like [[Tata Consultancy Services]] and [[Wipro]] also informed their stake holders about an expected material impact on its third-quarter earnings due to the floods and then to the low volume revenue during Christmas and New Year holidays in the west.{{cite news|title=After TCS, Wipro issues Q3 revenue warning over Chennai floods|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/industry/companies/after-tcs-wipro-issues-q3-revenue-warning-over-chennai-floods/179424/|accessdate=18 December 2015|work=The Financial Express|date=16 December 2015}} Car makers were also hugely affected due to shut down of plants, thus leading to lower production volume. German automaker [[BMW]] expected to resume production only from January 2016 while the American auto maker [[Ford]] started its plant only in late December 2015. The estimated production loss cost of BMW was about {{INRConvert|250|C}} and Ford's was about {{INRConvert|600|C}}.{{cite news|author1=Ketan Thakkar|title=Chennai floods: Carmakers like Ford and BMW struggle to restart work after screeching halt|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/news/passenger-vehicle/cars/chennai-floods-carmakers-like-ford-and-bmw-struggle-to-restart-work-after-screeching-halt/articleshow/50178816.cms|accessdate=18 December 2015|work=The Economic Times|date=15 December 2015}} ==Relief efforts== ===Tamil Nadu=== [[File:Indian Navy relief efforts during the 2015 floods in Chennai (04).jpg|thumb|right|Relief efforts by the Indian Navy in Chennai]] Tamil Nadu Chief Minister [[Jayalalithaa]] announced an initial allocation of {{INRConvert|500|c|0}} for relief and rehousing, with {{INRConvert|4|l|0}} for each family who had lost relatives in the floods. 12 cyclone shelters were built in [[Nagapattinam district]], while 11 teams of the [[National Disaster Response Force]] (NDRF) were dispatched to Tamil Nadu. Over 10,000 people had been rescued by 14 to 27 November and dozens of relief camps established .The [[Indian Air Force]] deployed four helicopters to airlift flood victims from inundated parts of Chennai city. Over 5,300 people had been rescued by 16 November and dozens of relief camps established.{{cite news|title=Rain batters TN: Jaya announces Rs 500cr relief, IAF in action|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/rain-batters-tn-jaya-announces-rs-500cr-relief-iaf-in-action/story-RQIQUQzbTUIk7QTcVYRuEN.html|accessdate=16 November 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=16 November 2015}}{{cite news|title=Eleven NDRF teams rushed to Tamil Nadu |url=http://or-politics.com/u-s-world/eleven-ndrf-teams-rushed-to-tamil-nadu/155298/ |accessdate=16 November 2015 |publisher=Or-politics |date=16 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032738/http://or-politics.com/u-s-world/eleven-ndrf-teams-rushed-to-tamil-nadu/155298/ |archivedate=17 November 2015 }} Political parties in Tamil Nadu demanded swift action and the allocation of central government relief funds. Opposition party [[Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (DMK) donated {{INRConvert|1|c|0}} to the state government on behalf of the party. DMK leader [[Karunanidhi]] however criticised the government's disbursement of {{INRConvert|500|c|0}} as insufficient considering the amount of damage resulting from the floods. He and local [[Communist Party of India]] state secretary R Mutharasan urged efforts to obtain large amounts of federal disaster relief funding; Karunanidhi further suggested soliciting funds "from the rich in Tamil Nadu for disaster relief and the establishment of party monitoring committees to ensure a speedy disbursal of relief "without any discrimination". [[Anbumani Ramadoss]], [[Lok Sabha]] MP from the [[Pattali Makkal Katchi]] demanded an immediate {{INRConvert|5000|0}} be disbursed to families that had lost their livelihoods because of the flooding. [[File:Indian Navy relief efforts during the 2015 floods in Chennai (02).jpg|thumb|left|Indian Navy officers distribute drinking water in Chennai]] The [[Indian Coast Guard]] and the three other branches of the [[Indian Armed Forces]] conducted rescue operations across Tamil Nadu, with the Indian Army and Air Force rescuing people in Kancheepuram district.{{cite news|title=Tamil Nadu rains: Mild showers expected in Chennai; death toll touches 79|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-tamil-nadu-rains-mild-showers-expected-in-chennai-death-toll-touches-79-2146199|accessdate=17 November 2015|work=Daily News and Analysis|date=17 November 2015}} The IAF conducted 25 sorties in Tamil Nadu and in Andhra Pradesh, air-dropping 5000 kg of supplies and rescuing 25 stranded people before ceasing operations on 20 November.{{cite news|title=Indian Air Force (IAF) Winds up Relief and Rescue Operations in Flood Hit Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/government-press-release/indian-air-force-iaf-winds-up-relief-and-rescue-operations-in-115112001064_1.html|accessdate=20 November 2015|work=Business Standard|date=20 November 2015}} Uninterrupted power supply had been restored in 671 of the 683 [[village panchayat]]s in Cuddalore district, with the remaining panchayats supplied with drinking water through tanker lorries. 40 medical camps and 121 special camps for cattle stock had been constructed and 70 relief camps had distributed 58,000 food packets. Upwards of 5,335 people living in low-lying areas had been evacuated and over 90,000 food packets distributed in 101 relief camps. In Tiruvallur district, 18,501 food packets were distributed through 57 relief camps and 2,958 people had been given shelter. In Kancheepuram district, people in low-lying areas had been moved to safety and 16,000 food packets distributed. It was reported on 18 November that 55,000 people across Tamil Nadu had been screened for water- and vector-borne diseases in medical camps, while a further 402 mobile medical units were operating.{{cite news|title=Steps afoot to prevent disease outbreak in Tamil Nadu; 55,000 people screened|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/steps-afoot-to-prevent-disease-outbreak-in-tamil-nadu-55000-people-screened/articleshow/49831313.cms|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=The Economic Times|date=18 November 2015}} On 22 November, the central government released an initial {{INRConvert|939.63|c|0}} for immediate relief efforts in the state,{{cite news|title=Jaya wants Rs 2,000-cr immediate flood aid, gets Rs 940 cr for now |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/jaya-wants-rs-2-000-cr-immediate-flood-aid-gets-rs-940-cr-for-now/story-Lkk4AJ0sh90HYhEmXt6KAJ.html|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=23 November 2015}} sanctioning a further {{INRConvert|1000|c|0}} on 3 December.{{cite news|title=Modi announces Rs.1,000 cr for Tamil Nadu flood relief|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/chennai-floods-latest-updates-relief-rescue-operation-underway-imd-predicts-more-rains/article7944526.ece|accessdate=3 December 'Sunk Monday' |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/The-Day-Chennai-Drowned-City-Experiences-Sunk-Monday/2015/11/17/article3131878.ece|accessdate=17 November 2015|work=The New Indian
